channel.title: Equation solver

item.title: Equation solver
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

[quote=“Strucker, post:36, topic:520510”]@Taharok, i finally got the gauss elimination method to work and it works!, do you have any ideas on how it could be optimized or something?

[code=java]import javax.swing.JOptionPane;

/**

  • Solves equation with the gauss method
  • @author Strucker, @author alejandrou7

*/
public class GaussEquationSolver extends JOptionPane {

/*
 * used to see how many variables the program is going to solve
 */
public static int n;

public static int m;

public static String text;

public static double matrix[][];

public static int i;

public static int j;

public static int k;

public static int l;

public static int w;

public static double multiplier;

public static double divider;

/*
 * Solves the equation
 */
public static void solver() {
	for (int i = 0; i < n; i++) {
		for (int j = 0; j < n; j++) {

			w = n - j - 1;

			if (i == w) {

			} else {
				multiplier = matrix[i][i] / matrix[n - j - 1][i] * -1;
				for (k = 0; k < m; k++) {
					matrix[n - j - 1][k] = matrix[n - j - 1][k]
							* multiplier + matrix[i][k];
				}
			}
		}

	}
	for (int i = 0; i < n; i++) {
		divider = matrix[i][i];
		for (int k = 0; k < m; k++) {
			matrix[i][k] = matrix[i][k] / divider;
		}
	}
}

public static int YI = i+1;
public static void printer() {
	for (int i = 0; i < n; i++) {
		if(i== 0){
		showMessageDialog(null, "incognite 1 = "+matrix[i][m - 1]+"");
		} else {
			
			showMessageDialog(null, "incognite "+YI+" = "+matrix[i][m - 1]+"");
		}
	}
}

/*
 * runs the program1
 */
public static void main(String[] args) {

	String variables = JOptionPane
			.showInputDialog("Enter the number of equations to be solved");
	n = Integer.parseInt(variables);
	m = n + 1;
	matrix = new double[n][m];

	for (i = 0; i < n; i++) {
		l = i + 1;
		for (j = 0; j < m; j++) {
			k = j + 1;
			if (j < m - 1) {

				text = "enter the coefficent " + k + " of the equation "
						+ l + "";
			} else {

				text = "enter the constant of equation " + l + " ";
			}

			String p = JOptionPane.showInputDialog("" + text + "");

			matrix[i][j] = Double.parseDouble(p);
			System.out.print(matrix[i][j]);

		}

	}

	solver();
	printer();
}

}
[/code]
And i know the code is kinda redundant in some parts but i had not idea on what i was doing lol[/quote]

Well, I would be careful in regards to completely zero rows, for starters. If I’m not mistaken, you will have a divide by zero problem in your code. You also don’t need to use doubles for something like this, unless you really feel the need to. floats are more than likely to produce the precision you need and, if you’re running in x86 mode (on a 32bit architecture or at least with 32-bit Java VM), they will be faster than doubles in a lot of ways.

Otherwise just quickly glancing shows me something sppt pointed out. You really want to use local variables as much as you can, especially for time-crunching code. You could start looking up other solutions to gauss-jordan. Some are really neat approaches to solving it. People have figured out ways that you’d never think of, so it’s a good learning experience.

Read full topic

item.title: Equation solver
item.dc:creator: @strucker Strucker
item.description:
@strucker wrote:

[quote=“sppt, post:37, topic:520510”]Try to use local variables more often, putting everything in the global scope is rather ugly and can be detrimental to memory usage.
Also, use better variables names, not just for others, but also for yourself, the less confusing variable names you use, the easier it is to program.

Also, the YI variable you declared will always evaluate to the same value in your printer() method, the way you’ve done it now ensures the expression gets evaluated once, when the class gets initialized.

Just a little bit of nitpicking, but whenever you use javadoc, every single @-tag should be on it’s own line, this piece of jdoc

[code]/**

  • Solves equation with the gauss method
  • @author Strucker, @author alejandrou7
    */[/code]

should really be

[code]/**

  • Solves equation with the gauss method
  • @author Strucker
  • @author alejandrou7
    */[/code]

You really should pick up a decent java book (I don’t know which ones are good, been awhile) to learn the basics, there’s things that books and stuff explain really well (for example, why you shouldn’t be using static for everything, in this case it’s not a big mistake) and will help you program better and that stuff[/quote]Thanks for the feedback, and yeah… i’ve been reading some docs recently…

Read full topic

item.title: Equation solver
item.dc:creator: @sppt sppt
item.description:
@sppt wrote:

Try to use local variables more often, putting everything in the global scope is rather ugly and can be detrimental to memory usage.
Also, use better variables names, not just for others, but also for yourself, the less confusing variable names you use, the easier it is to program.

Also, the YI variable you declared will always evaluate to the same value in your printer() method, the way you’ve done it now ensures the expression gets evaluated once, when the class gets initialized.

Just a little bit of nitpicking, but whenever you use javadoc, every single @-tag should be on it’s own line, this piece of jdoc

[code]/**

  • Solves equation with the gauss method
  • @author Strucker, @author alejandrou7
    */[/code]

should really be

[code]/**

  • Solves equation with the gauss method
  • @author Strucker
  • @author alejandrou7
    */[/code]

You really should pick up a decent java book (I don’t know which ones are good, been awhile) to learn the basics, there’s things that books and stuff explain really well (for example, why you shouldn’t be using static for everything, in this case it’s not a big mistake) and will help you program better and that stuff

Read full topic

item.title: Equation solver
item.dc:creator: @strucker Strucker
item.description:
@strucker wrote:

@Taharok, i finally got the gauss elimination method to work and it works!, do you have any ideas on how it could be optimized or something?

[code=java]import javax.swing.JOptionPane;

/**

  • Solves equation with the gauss method
  • @author Strucker, @author alejandrou7

*/
public class GaussEquationSolver extends JOptionPane {

/*
 * used to see how many variables the program is going to solve
 */
public static int n;

public static int m;

public static String text;

public static double matrix[][];

public static int i;

public static int j;

public static int k;

public static int l;

public static int w;

public static double multiplier;

public static double divider;

/*
 * Solves the equation
 */
public static void solver() {
	for (int i = 0; i < n; i++) {
		for (int j = 0; j < n; j++) {

			w = n - j - 1;

			if (i == w) {

			} else {
				multiplier = matrix[i][i] / matrix[n - j - 1][i] * -1;
				for (k = 0; k < m; k++) {
					matrix[n - j - 1][k] = matrix[n - j - 1][k]
							* multiplier + matrix[i][k];
				}
			}
		}

	}
	for (int i = 0; i < n; i++) {
		divider = matrix[i][i];
		for (int k = 0; k < m; k++) {
			matrix[i][k] = matrix[i][k] / divider;
		}
	}
}

public static int YI = i+1;
public static void printer() {
	for (int i = 0; i < n; i++) {
		if(i== 0){
		showMessageDialog(null, "incognite 1 = "+matrix[i][m - 1]+"");
		} else {
			
			showMessageDialog(null, "incognite "+YI+" = "+matrix[i][m - 1]+"");
		}
	}
}

/*
 * runs the program1
 */
public static void main(String[] args) {

	String variables = JOptionPane
			.showInputDialog("Enter the number of equations to be solved");
	n = Integer.parseInt(variables);
	m = n + 1;
	matrix = new double[n][m];

	for (i = 0; i < n; i++) {
		l = i + 1;
		for (j = 0; j < m; j++) {
			k = j + 1;
			if (j < m - 1) {

				text = "enter the coefficent " + k + " of the equation "
						+ l + "";
			} else {

				text = "enter the constant of equation " + l + " ";
			}

			String p = JOptionPane.showInputDialog("" + text + "");

			matrix[i][j] = Double.parseDouble(p);
			System.out.print(matrix[i][j]);

		}

	}

	solver();
	printer();
}

}
[/code]
And i know the code is kinda redundant in some parts but i had not idea on what i was doing lol

item.title: Equation solver
item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

I wrote a quick code for reading your lines and putting it into a matrix, I haven’t tested it completely, but it might be something usable in it.

Taharok: Sorry if you think this is shit. There is probably many things to improve in the code.

[code]import javax.swing.JOptionPane;

public class Ligningssystem {
public static void main(String args[]){
new Ligningssystem();
}

public double[][] matrix;
public int size;
public int index = 0;
public Ligningssystem(){
	init();
	for (double[] x : matrix) {
		for(double y : x){
			System.out.print(y + " ");
		}
		System.out.print("\n");
	}

}

public void init(){
	try{
	size = Integer.parseInt(JOptionPane.showInputDialog("How many equations do the problem contain?"));
	matrix = new double[size][size + 1];
	
	for(int i = 0; i < size; i++){
		readLine(JOptionPane.showInputDialog("Write the next equation"));
	}
	
	}catch(Exception e){
		System.out.println("Input not accepted");
		
	}
	
}

// Reads one line at the index, put the equation into the matrix and increase the index by one.
public void readLine(String input){
input = input.replace(" ", “”);
double[] m = matrix[index++];
String currentNumber = “”;
int variableIndex = 0;
boolean fortegn = true;

	/* 	Parces through the string. 
		If a operator (+ / -) it stores that value.
		If a number, add the number onto a tempoary string for the number.
		If a equal sign, get the solution to the equation.
		If a letter, stores the current number at the variableIndex, and increase the index by one.


	*/		
	for(int i = 0; i < input.length(); i++){
		char sign = input.charAt(i);
		if(isOperator(sign))
			fortegn = getOperator(sign);
		
		else if(isNumber(input.charAt(i))){
			currentNumber += input.charAt(i);
		}else if(isLetter(sign)){
			if(currentNumber != ""){
			m[variableIndex++] = (fortegn) ? Integer.parseInt(currentNumber) : -Integer.parseInt(currentNumber);
			currentNumber = "";
			}
			else{ m[variableIndex++] = (fortegn) ? 1 : -1;
			}
			
			
		} else if(isEqualsign(sign)){
			input = input.substring(i + 1);
			m[variableIndex] = Integer.parseInt(input);
		}
	}
}


// Functions to decide if the character is a number, operator, equal sign or a letter. It regards everything that is not a number/operator/equal sign as a letter, so '!' will be regarded as a letter, but this is not a problem, as the program doesn't use it anyway.

public boolean isNumber(char sign){
	if((int)sign >= 48 && (int)sign <= 57){
		return true;
	}
	return false;
}

public boolean isOperator(char sign){
	if(sign == 43 || sign == 45)
		return true;
	else return false;
}

public boolean isEqualsign(char sign){
	if((int) sign == 61)
		return true;
	else return false;
}

public boolean getOperator(char sign){
	if((int) sign == 43)
		return true;
	else return false;
}

public boolean isLetter(char sign){
	if(isEqualsign(sign) || isOperator(sign) || isNumber(sign))
			return false;
	else return true;
}

}
[/code]

Read full topic

item.title: Equation solver
item.dc:creator: @strucker Strucker
item.description:
@strucker wrote:

[quote=“Taharok, post:21, topic:520510”]It’s a good start, but you can definitely build on it. As was mentioned, it would be cool to allow users to input the equations directly, automatically figuring out what variables to extract. This isn’t as complicated as it seems. Just strip the line of all whitespace, then extract the coefficients assuming only addition or subtraction separates the terms, plus there must be an equals to a constant at the end.

While you’re there, why stop at 2 equations? If you are familiar with how reduced row echelon form works, it makes it fundamentally easy to solve systems of n equations using a n x n+1 matrix. The algorithm for solving reduced row echelon form can be broken up into 2 processes, a top-down process for putting a matrix into echelon form, then a bottom-up method for putting it into reduced form. You use 3 elementary row operations (swap, multiply by a non-zero constant, and add a constant-multiplied row into another row), and deciding which to use can be as simple as checking the numbers under (first part) or over (second part) the pivots of each row. The pivots are always along the diagonal, so finding their positions is pretty easy, too. Then you know all the values left of a pivot in each row must be zero and all the values above a pivot must be zero. Then you can just extract the last column’s values, which reads out the solutions of each of the variables (unless there is no solution, in which case the left side of the matrix has a row of all zeros or an impossible solution (wherein it ends up being 0x+0y+…+0z=1 or something)). This is the process of gauss-jordan elimination.

If you do end up taking that route, as far as parsing is concerned, make sure that you ORDER the variables in each equation to match the other equations (ie, all x’s could be first, then y’s, then z’s, etc.) Otherwise gauss-jordan elimination does not work.[/quote]Well, im an 8th grader, but well i’m trying to do it with help from my brother, and i’ve encountered a problem… i have this:

[code=java]import javax.swing.JOptionPane;

/**

  • Solves equation with the gauss method
  • @author Strucker, thanks to my brother who helped too much, thanks also to
  •     taharok, or/and any one else who replied, because you were made me do

  •     this.

*/
public class GaussEcuationSolver {

/*
 * used to see how many variables the program is going to solve
 */
public static int n;

/*
 * runs the program1
 */
public static void main(String[] args) {
	String variables = JOptionPane
			.showInputDialog("Enter the number of equations to be solved");
	n = Integer.parseInt(variables);
	int m = n + 1;
	for (int i = 1; i < m; i++) {
		
	}
}

}
[/code]
what it means is that n is the number of equations, but is there any way that i can generate an array using the “n” value? i’ve tried some things, and… didn’t work, i mean i want the array to be created depending on the n, do you understand me?

[quote=“Davidi2, post:20, topic:520510”]I can understand wanting shorthand for System.out.println (java 8 lambda pls), but it is quite funny that you used sM :P[/quote] lol yea grrr

Read full topic

item.title: Equation solver
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

It’s a good start, but you can definitely build on it. As was mentioned, it would be cool to allow users to input the equations directly, automatically figuring out what variables to extract. This isn’t as complicated as it seems. Just strip the line of all whitespace, then extract the coefficients assuming only addition or subtraction separates the terms, plus there must be an equals to a constant at the end.

While you’re there, why stop at 2 equations? If you are familiar with how reduced row echelon form works, it makes it fundamentally easy to solve systems of n equations using a n x n+1 matrix. The algorithm for solving reduced row echelon form can be broken up into 2 processes, a top-down process for putting a matrix into echelon form, then a bottom-up method for putting it into reduced form. You use 3 elementary row operations (swap, multiply by a non-zero constant, and add a constant-multiplied row into another row), and deciding which to use can be as simple as checking the numbers under (first part) or over (second part) the pivots of each row. The pivots are always along the diagonal, so finding their positions is pretty easy, too. Then you know all the values left of a pivot in each row must be zero and all the values above a pivot must be zero. Then you can just extract the last column’s values, which reads out the solutions of each of the variables (unless there is no solution, in which case the left side of the matrix has a row of all zeros or an impossible solution (wherein it ends up being 0x+0y+…+0z=1 or something)). This is the process of gauss-jordan elimination.

If you do end up taking that route, as far as parsing is concerned, make sure that you ORDER the variables in each equation to match the other equations (ie, all x’s could be first, then y’s, then z’s, etc.) Otherwise gauss-jordan elimination does not work.
